sanskrit:
बन्धुरात्मात्मनस्तस्य येनात्मैवात्मना जितः।
अनात्मनस्तु शत्रुत्वे वर्तेतात्मैव शत्रुवत्॥
transliteration:
bandhur ātmātmanas tasya yenātmaivātmanā jitaḥ |
anātmanas tu śatrutve vartetātmaiva śatruvat ||
translation: For one who has conquered the mind, the Self is the best of friends; but for one who has failed to do so, the very Self acts as the greatest enemy.
commentary:
This verse presents a profound psychological and spiritual truth about the dual nature of the mind. Krishna explains that the mind can be either our greatest ally or our worst adversary, depending on whether we have mastered it. When one has conquered the lower self (mind and senses) through discipline and practice, the higher Self becomes a friend, guiding one toward liberation and inner peace. The term 'ātman' here refers both to the individual self (mind-body complex) and the Supreme Self, indicating their potential unity when properly aligned.

The verse emphasizes personal responsibility in spiritual development. The mind that is uncontrolled becomes hostile to one's own welfare, constantly pulling the individual toward sense gratification, creating suffering through attachment and aversion. Conversely, a disciplined mind becomes the instrument of self-realization, helping one transcend limitations and experience the true nature of consciousness. This teaching is central to the practice of dhyana yoga, where the practitioner must first establish mastery over the mind before deeper meditation can occur.

The philosophical significance lies in understanding that liberation is not achieved through external means but through internal transformation. The battle is within oneself—between the higher aspirations of the soul and the lower tendencies of the uncontrolled mind. This verse serves as both a warning and an encouragement: it warns of the dangers of an undisciplined mind while encouraging the seeker that victory over the mind transforms it from foe to friend, making spiritual progress not only possible but natural.
speaker: Krishna
